summary: This document is an email chain from August 2019 concerning the scheduling of a telephonic court hearing for inmate Wilbert Kitson Turner at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) in New York. It includes a forwarded request for a psychological observation log for Jeffrey Epstein from July 24-30, 2019, and administrative coordination to reserve a conference room for Turner's hearing, noting that Epstein would also likely have an attorney visit. This document is a collection of email correspondence and a court notice regarding inmate Nicholas 'Nick' Turner, who is incarcerated at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) in New York. The emails discuss his placement in the Special Housing Unit (SHU) for alleged cell phone possession, poor conditions in his cell, and the scheduling of a status conference for his civil case, Turner v. Ulloa. The communications are between legal staff at MCC, federal prosecutors, and Turner's defense attorney. This document contains email correspondence from July-August 2019 regarding conditions in the Special Housing Unit (SHU) for an inmate named 'Nick' and later regarding Jeffrey Epstein's telephone account and news articles about his death. It reveals legal and administrative communications between attorneys, prison staff, and prosecutors concerning inmate welfare and Epstein's incarceration. This document is a collection of emails and news clippings from August and December 2019. The primary content is a breaking news email about Jeffrey Epstein signing a $577 million will two days before his suicide, witnessed by a lawyer who represented El Chapo. It also includes other news clips and internal Bureau of Prisons emails regarding Epstein's incarceration, a missing surveillance video, and administrative matters. This document is an email from Associate Warden Charisma Edge forwarding a PDF attachment titled 'Epstein Psych Observation 7-24-30-2019.pdf'. The email and its metadata pertain to the psychological observation and suicide watch logs for inmate Jeffrey Epstein at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) New York from July 24-30, 2019, just prior to his death. The attached PDF appears to contain the detailed observation logs. This document is a prison observation log and related email concerning Jeffrey Epstein's psychological observation/suicide watch from July 24-30, 2019, while he was incarcerated. It includes a meal/shower chart, handwritten observation notes, and metadata for an email transmitting the log. This document is a forwarded email chain from January 8, 2020, discussing a court order in the case USA v. Conyers et al. It includes a suicide watch/psych observation log for an inmate (likely Jeffrey Epstein) and email correspondence between Bureau of Prisons (BOP) attorneys and staff regarding the court's order for a mental health treatment update for inmate Anthony Scott. This document contains email correspondence between Bureau of Prisons (BOP) staff and federal prosecutors regarding a court order in the USA v. Conyers et al. case and a separate email arranging a visit to the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) to inspect areas related to Jeffrey Epstein's incarceration and death. The emails show coordination between legal staff and prosecutors on case management and investigative access. This document contains email correspondence from August and November-December 2019. It includes a request from SDNY prosecutors to visit the MCC following Jeffrey Epstein's death, a media inquiry about charges against MCC staff, and internal BOP discussions about a Miami Herald report on systemic sexual abuse at a women's prison in Florida, linking it to broader BOP dysfunction highlighted by Epstein's death. This document is a series of email exchanges between Bureau of Prisons (BOP) officials discussing a Miami Herald article and lawsuit about systemic sexual abuse at the Coleman Federal Correctional Complex. The emails involve internal coordination on how to respond to inquiries from the Office of the Solicitor (OS) regarding statistics on sexual abuse allegations in BOP facilities. The article also references Jeffrey Epstein's death in BOP custody. This document contains email chains from the Bureau of Prisons (BOP) discussing a Miami Herald article and lawsuit about systemic sexual abuse at Coleman Federal Correctional Complex, and a separate email chain regarding a US Attorney's office tour of the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) following Jeffrey Epstein's death. It reveals internal BOP discussions about responding to media inquiries on sexual abuse statistics and logistical planning for a post-mortem facility tour. This document contains a detailed minute-by-minute timeline of the events surrounding Jeffrey Epstein's death in custody on August 10, 2019, at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) New York. It also includes an internal Bureau of Prisons (BOP) email from October 2019 discussing policy changes to inmate suicide prevention protocols following Epstein's suicide. This document contains email correspondence from December 2019 regarding a Miami Herald article about systemic sexual abuse at the Coleman Federal Correctional Complex, and includes an attached Bureau of Prisons (BOP) form related to a psychological observation of Jeffrey Epstein from July 2019. The emails discuss BOP's response to inquiries about sexual abuse statistics and investigations. This document is a Bureau of Prisons email and attached psychological observation log for inmate Jeffrey Epstein, covering the period from July 8 to July 10, 2019. It details his status on psychological observation/suicide watch at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) New York, including a meal/shower chart and staff observations. The email is sent among BOP staff regarding his status. This document contains internal Bureau of Prisons emails and a detailed timeline of events surrounding Jeffrey Epstein's death in custody at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) New York on August 10, 2019. It includes the minute-by-minute response, notifications to officials, and preparations for a visit by the US Attorney's office. This document contains email correspondence from August 2019 between Bureau of Prisons (BOP) staff and the US Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York (SDNY). It includes a request for a tour of the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) following Jeffrey Epstein's death, and subsequent internal BOP emails regarding a media inquiry about sewage flooding and staffing issues at the MCC in the wake of Epstein's suicide. This document contains email correspondence between Bureau of Prisons (BOP) staff regarding media inquiries about MCC staff charges related to Jeffrey Epstein's death, and separate emails between an attorney and BOP staff regarding the delivery of a CPAP machine for Epstein. It shows internal BOP communication about press strategy and logistical details concerning Epstein's medical equipment while incarcerated. This document contains email correspondence between Jeffrey Epstein's attorney, Jonathan Savella, and Bureau of Prisons official Adam Johnson regarding administrative matters for Epstein's incarceration, including the approval of a paralegal and delivery of a CPAP machine. It also includes forwarded Google Alerts about prison news and Epstein's death. This document contains email correspondence from August 2019 between Bureau of Prisons (BOP) staff and the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York (SDNY) arranging a tour of the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) following Jeffrey Epstein's death. The SDNY prosecutors request to see the suicide watch area, SHU, and Epstein's cordoned-off cell, specifying they will not speak to guards due to ongoing investigations. This document contains email correspondence between Bureau of Prisons (BOP) staff regarding a medical records request for Jeffrey Epstein and a press inquiry about MCC staff charges, along with Epstein's detailed medical records from July 2019. The medical records show Epstein reporting health issues including numbness, lack of medication, and sleep apnea while in custody at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) in New York. A series of Bureau of Prisons (BOP) clinical encounter notes for inmate Jeffrey Epstein at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) New York, covering the period from his intake in early July 2019 to July 24, 2019. The records document his medical history, routine care, and crucially, the assessment of injuries sustained on July 23, 2019, where he was found with a rope around his neck and later insinuated his cellmate was involved. This document is a compilation of Bureau of Prisons (BOP) medical records for inmate Jeffrey Epstein from July 6 to July 30, 2019, while he was held at the Metropolitan Correctional Center, New York (NYM). It includes initial intake assessments, physical exams, vital signs, lab orders, and medication records, documenting his health status in the weeks leading up to his death. This document is a compilation of Bureau of Prisons medical, dental, and psychological records for inmate Jeffrey Epstein (Reg #76318-054) from July 2019, while he was held at the Metropolitan Correctional Center, New York (MCC NY). It includes health assessments, medication lists, dietary restrictions, dental exams, and a psychological evaluation regarding his competency for a disciplinary process related to a self-injury incident. A series of Bureau of Prisons clinical psychology contact notes from late July 2019 documenting daily mental status evaluations of inmate Jeffrey Epstein while he was on psychological observation/suicide watch at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) New York. The notes detail his complaints about conditions in the Special Housing Unit (SHU), his inability to remember how he sustained neck injuries, his sleep issues, and his interactions with legal counsel. This document contains multiple Bureau of Prisons psychology reports from July 2019 regarding Jeffrey Epstein's mental health status while incarcerated at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) in New York. It includes a post-suicide watch report, suicide risk assessments, and clinical intervention notes following an incident where Epstein was found with a string around his neck. The reports document his psychological evaluations, denial of suicidal intent, and concerns about his safety in the SHU. This document contains Bureau of Prisons psychology services records for inmate Jeffrey Epstein from July 9-10, 2019, including a suicide risk assessment, diagnostic formulation, and clinical intervention notes. The records show Epstein was placed on precautionary psychological observation after returning from court, was assessed as having low suicide risk, and made various requests about his jail conditions while awaiting his bail hearing. This document contains multiple Bureau of Prisons psychological assessments for Jeffrey Epstein conducted shortly after his 2019 arrest. It includes a suicide risk assessment, intake screening, and risk of sexual abusiveness evaluation, all concluding he was at low risk, denied suicidal ideation, and was future-oriented about his legal case. This document is a collection of Bureau of Prisons medical records for Jeffrey Epstein from July 2019, including lab results, treatment refusal forms, and clinical encounter notes. It details his medical condition, refusals of recommended care, and a significant injury report from July 23, 2019, where he was found with a rope around his neck in his cell and placed on suicide watch. This document is a collection of Bureau of Prisons (BOP) health services records for inmate Jeffrey Epstein, covering his initial intake and follow-up medical encounters at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) New York (NYM) in July 2019, shortly after his arrest and before his death. The records detail his medical history, complaints, physical exams, and prescribed treatments. This document is a collection of Bureau of Prisons health services and psychology records for inmate Jeffrey Epstein from July 2019, covering medical examinations, vital signs, medication orders, and psychological assessments. It includes a detailed suicide risk assessment from July 23, 2019, after Epstein was found with a string around his neck, noting his claim that his cellmate tried to kill him. This document contains Bureau of Prisons psychology services records for inmate Jeffrey Epstein from July 9-12, 2019, including suicide risk assessments, clinical intervention notes, and diagnostic formulations. The records detail his mental state, complaints about prison conditions, and his anticipation of his bail hearing while incarcerated at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (NYM). This document contains a Bureau of Prisons suicide risk assessment and risk of sexual abusiveness assessment for Jeffrey Epstein, conducted on July 9, 2019, the day after a court proceeding. The assessment finds Epstein at low acute suicide risk and low risk of sexual abusiveness, noting his denial of suicidality, future orientation, and confidence in his attorney. This document is a collection of Bureau of Prisons medical and psychological records for inmate Jeffrey Epstein from July to August 2019. It includes an initial psychological intake screening, lab results, treatment refusals, chronic care visits, and a detailed emergency resuscitation note from the day he was found unresponsive in his cell. The records show his medical conditions, mental state, and the events leading to his death. This document is a series of Bureau of Prisons (BOP) Health Services clinical encounter notes for inmate Jeffrey Epstein from July 23-30, 2019, at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) New York (NYM). It details medical evaluations following an incident where Epstein was found with a rope around his neck, his subsequent placement on suicide watch, and ongoing complaints of numbness and other health issues. The notes include his cryptic statements about his cellmate's involvement and refusals to elaborate. This document is a collection of Bureau of Prisons (BOP) health services records for inmate Jeffrey Epstein, covering his initial intake and subsequent medical evaluations at the Metropolitan Correctional Center, New York (NYM) in July 2019. The records detail his medical history, complaints, physical exams, diagnoses, and treatment plans in the weeks leading up to his death. This document is a compilation of Bureau of Prisons (BOP) medical records for inmate Jeffrey Epstein, covering his intake health screening on July 9, 2019, and subsequent medical encounters, vitals, and treatment orders up to August 23, 2019, at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) in New York. It details his medical history, physical condition, and prescribed treatments, including for constipation, back pain, and prediabetes. This document is a compilation of Bureau of Prisons health services records for inmate Jeffrey Epstein (Reg #76318-054) from July 6, 2019, to August 23, 2019, at the New York Metropolitan Correctional Center (NYM). It includes medical assessments, diagnoses, medication logs, dental records, and psychological evaluations, including suicide risk assessments and a clinical intervention session. The records detail his physical and mental health status while in custody. This document contains a series of Bureau of Prisons psychology service clinical notes and reports from late July to early August 2019, detailing mental health assessments of Jeffrey Epstein while he was incarcerated at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) in New York. The notes focus on his mental status, suicide risk assessments, and competency evaluations following an incident on July 23, 2019, where he was found with a string around his neck in the SHU. The reports consistently note he denies suicidal ideation, is future-oriented, and is deemed psychologically stable with low acute suicide risk. This document contains a series of Bureau of Prisons psychology service clinical contact notes and a post-suicide watch report for inmate Jeffrey Epstein, covering July 24-28, 2019. The notes detail his mental status, his claims of having no memory of an incident that caused marks on his neck while in the Special Housing Unit (SHU), his complaints about SHU conditions, and his interactions with staff and inmate companions. The reports assess his suicide risk as low and step him down from suicide watch to psychological observation. A series of Bureau of Prisons psychology service records documenting mental health assessments and observations of Jeffrey Epstein while incarcerated at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) New York in July 2019. The documents include suicide risk assessments, clinical contacts, and administrative notes, culminating in the report of an incident on July 23, 2019, where Epstein was found with a string around his neck and placed on suicide watch. This document contains Bureau of Prisons psychological assessment forms for Jeffrey Epstein, including a Diagnostic and Care Level Formulation and multiple Suicide Risk Assessments conducted on July 9-10, 2019. The assessments were performed by Chief Psychologist Elissa Miller at the Metropolitan Correctional Center in New York (NYM) following Epstein's return from court on July 8, 2019. Epstein was placed on precautionary psychological observation but was found to have low acute suicide risk and no mental health diagnosis. This document contains Bureau of Prisons psychological and medical assessment records for Jeffrey Epstein from July 8-10, 2019, while he was incarcerated at MCC New York. It includes a suicide risk assessment, intake screening, risk of sexual abusiveness evaluation, and lab results, all concluding he was at low risk and in stable mental and physical health shortly before his death. This document contains Bureau of Prisons medical forms for Jeffrey Epstein from July 2019, including HIV counseling documentation and multiple medical treatment refusal forms. It is followed by a Washington Post article from September 2019 about the 2020 Democratic presidential primary, focusing on generational change among candidates. This document is a newsletter from PowerPost's Daily 202, covering various political news including Trump family dynamics, Brexit negotiations, collapsed Afghanistan peace talks, Hurricane Dorian response, Hong Kong protests, and congressional agenda. It contains no direct references to Jeffrey Epstein or his case. This document is a September 9, 2019, email newsletter from The Washington Post's 'The Daily 202'. It covers multiple news stories, including a review of the book 'She Said' about the Harvey Weinstein investigation, and a report on Jeffrey Epstein's financial ties to elite universities like MIT and Harvard, which led to resignations and investigations. This document is a forwarded email chain from July 2019 attached to a Washington Post 'Daily 202' newsletter from September 9, 2019. The newsletter covers the 2020 Democratic presidential primary race, focusing on generational dynamics, and includes a section on Jeffrey Epstein's ties to elite universities. The attached email appears to be internal prison/administrative correspondence regarding Epstein's incarceration. This document contains email correspondence among Bureau of Prisons (BOP) staff regarding inmate Jeffrey Epstein's mental capacity for disciplinary proceedings and a detailed timeline of events surrounding his death on August 10, 2019, at the Metropolitan Correctional Center in New York. It includes internal communications and a suicide timeline report. This document is a prison observation log and related email concerning Jeffrey Epstein's placement on psychological observation/suicide watch from July 8-10, 2019, at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) New York. It includes a detailed log of his activities, meals, and behavior, and an email chain distributing this information among prison staff.

events.title: Epstein Psychological Observation
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was placed on psychological observation (or suicide watch) at MCC New York. A log documents his status, meals, and activities during this period.

events.title: Scheduled Telephonic Hearing for Inmate Turner
events.description: A telephonic court hearing for inmate Wilbert Kitson Turner with Judge Steven Weissman of the SDNY was scheduled for 10:00 AM, requiring coordination to reserve a conference room at MCC NY.

events.title: Rescheduled Status Conference for Turner v. Ulloa
events.description: An in-person status conference was rescheduled from August 9 to August 8, 2019, at 10:00 a.m. before Judge Lisa Margaret Smith. Pro se plaintiff Turner was to participate by telephone.

events.title: Turner Placed in SHU for Cell Phone Allegation
events.description: Inmate Nick Turner was placed in the Special Housing Unit (SHU) at MCC based on an allegation he was in possession of a cell phone.

events.title: Complaint about SHU Conditions for Nick
events.description: Attorney Bruce Barket emails prison and DOJ officials complaining that his client Nick has been placed in SHU, his cell toilet is leaking, and his legal documents have been confiscated.

events.title: Scheduling Call on SHU Conditions
events.description: Email exchange between AUSA Jason Swergold and prison attorneys Adam Johnson and Stephanie Scannell to schedule a call to discuss the SHU conditions and cellphone allegation regarding Nick.

events.title: Request to Establish Epstein's Phone Account
events.description: Attorney Jonathan Savella emails Adam Johnson requesting assistance to help Jeffrey Epstein establish a telephone account at the MCC, noting a unit manager had started the process.

events.title: Barr Comments on Epstein Suicide Irregularities
events.description: News article forwarded via email reports Attorney General William Barr stating investigators are uncovering 'serious irregularities' at the NYC federal lockup where Jeffrey Epstein died by suicide.

events.title: News on Epstein's Will
events.description: News article forwarded via email reports Jeffrey Epstein signed a will worth $577 million two days before his suicide, with 'El Chapo lawyer' as a witness.

events.title: Epstein signs final will
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein signed a will declaring he was worth $577 million, witnessed by lawyer Mariel Colon Miro.

events.title: Epstein's suicide
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein hanged himself in a federal jail.

events.title: Epstein's first suicide attempt
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein's first reported suicide effort in July; video surveillance footage from that time is reported missing.

events.title: Manafort charges dismissed
events.description: New York Judge Maxwell Wiley dismissed state fraud charges against Paul Manafort on double-jeopardy grounds.

events.title: Ebbers granted compassionate release
events.description: Federal Judge Valerie E. Caproni granted a compassionate release to former WorldCom CEO Bernard Ebbers, allowing him to leave prison early due to failing health.

events.title: USAO visit to MCC arranged
events.description: A visit by the U.S. Attorney's Office (USAO) to the Metropolitan Correctional Center was arranged to see the psych observation area, SHU, and Epstein's cell.

events.title: Start of Epstein's Psychological Observation
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was placed on psychological observation/suicide watch at MCC New York.

events.title: End of Documented Observation Period
events.description: The formal psychological observation period documented in the attached logs ended.

events.title: Email Forwarding Observation Logs
events.description: Associate Warden Charisma Edge emailed the psychological observation logs for Jeffrey Epstein (dated July 24-30) to at least one BOP recipient.

events.title: Start of Psych Observation for Epstein
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein placed on psychological observation/suicide watch in prison.

events.title: End of Psych Observation for Epstein
events.description: The scheduled end date for Jeffrey Epstein's psychological observation period.

events.title: Observation Log Transmitted
events.description: Email transmission of the psychological observation log for Jeffrey Epstein from July 24-30, 2019.

events.title: Court Order for Mental Health Update
events.description: Judge Valerie E. Caproni signs an order in case USA v. Conyers et al, requiring the government to provide an update on inmate Anthony Scott's mental health treatment by March 10, 2020.

events.title: Internal BOP Email Discussion
events.description: BOP attorneys Stephanie Scannell-Vessella, Christina Kelley, and others discuss the court order and decide to contact AUSA Samson Enzer directly for follow-up.

events.title: Court Order in USA v. Conyers et al.
events.description: Judge Valerie E. Caproni signs an order requiring the government to provide a status update on defendant Anthony Scott's mental health treatment by March 10, 2020.

events.title: Planned MCC Visit by Prosecutors
events.description: Federal prosecutors from the SDNY U.S. Attorney's Office request a visit to the Metropolitan Correctional Center to inspect the 9th floor SHU, psych observation/suicide watch area, and Jeffrey Epstein's cordoned-off cell.

events.title: Death of Jeffrey Epstein
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was found hanged in his cell at the Metropolitan Correctional Center in Manhattan.

events.title: SDNY Request to Visit MCC
events.description: Prosecutors from the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York requested a tour of the MCC, including Epstein's cell, the psych observation area, and the SHU.

events.title: AP Inquiry on MCC Staff Charges
events.description: Associated Press reporter Michael Sisak inquired about potential criminal charges against two MCC employees related to lapses the night of Epstein's death.

events.title: Miami Herald Report on Prison Abuse
events.description: The Miami Herald published an investigation detailing systemic sexual abuse of female inmates by male officers at the Coleman Federal Correctional Complex in Florida.

events.title: BOP Internal Discussion on Abuse Report
events.description: BOP officials, including Acting Director Hugh Hurwitz, discussed and compiled data in response to DOJ questions about the Miami Herald report on sexual abuse at Coleman prison.

events.title: Miami Herald publishes article on sexual abuse at Coleman
events.description: Miami Herald publishes an investigation titled 'Rape is rampant at this women's prison. Anyone who complains is punished, lawsuit says.' detailing systemic sexual abuse by male officers at the Coleman Federal Correctional Complex women's work camp.

events.title: DOJ/BOP internal email chain on abuse article
events.description: Internal email chain among BOP officials discussing the Miami Herald article and coordinating a response to inquiries from the Office of the Solicitor regarding sexual abuse statistics.

events.title: Jeffrey Epstein found dead in BOP custody
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein is found hanged in his cell at the Metropolitan Correctional Center in Manhattan, an event described as a suicide that led to the summary removal of the acting BOP director.

events.title: Lawsuit filed by 14 women against BOP/Coleman
events.description: Fourteen women file a lawsuit against the United States over sexual abuse endured at the Coleman Federal Correctional Complex women's camp, seeking compensation and prison overhaul.

events.title: Miami Herald publishes article on sexual abuse at Coleman prison
events.description: The Miami Herald I-Team publishes an investigation into systemic sexual abuse, harassment, and medical neglect at Lowell Correctional Institution (Coleman women's camp), leading to a lawsuit filed by 14 women.

events.title: Jeffrey Epstein found dead at MCC
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein is found hanged in his cell at the Metropolitan Correctional Center in Manhattan, an event described as a suicide.

events.title: Planned US Attorney tour of MCC
events.description: The US Attorney for the Southern District of New York (Geoffrey Berman) and his staff schedule a tour of the MCC's Special Housing Unit (SHU), suicide watch areas, and Epstein's cordoned-off cell.

events.title: BOP sexual abuse case statistics
events.description: Beth Reese provides raw numbers of staff/inmate sexual abuse cases investigated by the BOP Office of Internal Affairs for fiscal years 2014 through 2019, noting charges are sustained in fewer than 5% of cases.

events.title: Epstein's Final Full Day
events.description: Epstein spends the day in attorney conferences. His cellmate, Reyes Efrain, departs for court in the morning. In the evening, Epstein is reported to be in 'good spirits' during a social call.

events.title: Epstein Found Unresponsive and Pronounced Dead
events.description: At 6:33 am, a body alarm is activated. Staff find Epstein unresponsive in his cell. CPR is initiated, EMS is called, and he is transported to Beekman Hospital. He is pronounced dead at 7:36 am by an ER physician.

events.title: Official Notifications and Investigation Launch
events.description: Following the death, the FBI, AUSA, Judge Berman, Epstein's next of kin (brother), and the OIG are notified. The institution is placed on modified operations. The FBI and OIG arrive to investigate.

events.title: Evidence Collection by OIG
events.description: OIG Agents John Kerwin and Guido Modano arrive, remove two computer hard drives from the SHU, and depart with them as evidence.

events.title: Internal BOP Suicide Prevention Policy Discussion
events.description: Heidi Kugler emails Hugh Hurwitz and Alison Leukefeld about a new memo on inmate suicide prevention. The memo addresses wardens being overly cautious with suicide watch following Epstein's death, urging them to rely more on psychologists' expertise.

events.title: Jeffrey Epstein found dead in cell
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was found hanged in his cell at the Metropolitan Correctional Center in Manhattan.

events.title: Jeffrey Epstein placed on psychological observation
events.description: Epstein was placed on a psychological observation from 6 pm on July 8, 2019, until 9 am on July 10, 2019.

events.title: BOP email chain regarding sexual abuse inquiry
events.description: Email correspondence among BOP officials discussing response to questions from the Office of the Solicitor about sexual abuse statistics and investigations at BOP facilities.

events.title: Epstein Placed on Psychological Observation
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein is placed on psychological observation/suicide watch at the Metropolitan Correctional Center, New York.

events.title: End of Psychological Observation Period
events.description: The scheduled end of the psychological observation period for Jeffrey Epstein.

events.title: Email Transmission of Observation Log
events.description: Lanett N'Diaye sends an email with the attached psychological observation log for Jeffrey Epstein to other BOP staff.

events.title: Follow-up Email on Epstein's Status
events.description: Lee Plourde sends a follow-up email to multiple BOP staff regarding Jeffrey Epstein, referencing his registration number.

events.title: Epstein's last full day
events.description: Epstein meets with attorneys throughout the day. His cellmate, Reyes Efrain, departs for court and does not return.

events.title: Epstein found unresponsive and pronounced dead
events.description: At 6:33 am, staff find Epstein unresponsive in his cell. CPR is initiated, EMS transports him to Beekman Hospital, and he is pronounced dead at 7:36 am. A detailed institutional response follows.

events.title: Investigation and evidence collection begins
events.description: FBI and OIG are notified and arrive. The body is released for autopsy. Computer hard drives are removed from the SHU and replaced.

events.title: OIG agents collect computer evidence
events.description: OIG Agents John Kerwin and Guido Modano arrive, and Kerwin departs with two computers from the SHU.

events.title: National coordinators and regional director visit
events.description: National suicide prevention and sex offender program coordinators, along with the Northeast Regional Director, arrive at the institution.

events.title: Scheduled US Attorney visit
events.description: US Attorney Geoffrey Berman and his staff schedule a tour of the SHU, suicide watch areas, and Epstein's cell, requesting only MCC legal staff escort them.

events.title: SDNY Tour Request of MCC
events.description: The US Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York requests a tour of the MCC's suicide watch area, SHU, and Epstein's cell, which is still cordoned off.

events.title: Media Inquiry on MCC Flooding
events.description: Reporter Jake Offenhartz inquires about raw sewage flooding jail cells, female detainees being asked to clean up, and staffing shortages at the MCC in the wake of Epstein's suicide.

events.title: BOP Confirms MCC Sewage Backup
events.description: The BOP's Office of Public Affairs confirms a sewage backup at MCC New York that was repaired, units cleaned, and elevators returned to normal by noon; also confirms visitation was delayed due to staffing.

events.title: Jeffrey Epstein's Suicide
events.description: Referenced as the precipitating event for increased scrutiny on MCC conditions and staffing. The exact date (2019-08-10) is inferred from context.

events.title: AP Inquiry about MCC Staff Charges
events.description: Associated Press reporter Michael Sisak emails BOP inquiring if their attorney is representing two MCC employees about to be charged regarding lapses the night of Epstein's death.

events.title: Approval for Epstein's CPAP Machine
events.description: BOP staff member Adam Johnson informs attorney Jonathan Savella that medical staff can accept a CPAP machine for inmate Jeffrey Epstein.

events.title: Scheduled CPAP Machine Delivery
events.description: Attorney Jonathan Savella informs BOP staff he will deliver Epstein's CPAP machine to the MCC lobby around 12:30 PM, asking them to notify Mr. Yannone.

events.title: Paralegal Application Submitted
events.description: Jonathan Savella emails Adam Johnson to submit Samanta Honigman's application to serve as a paralegal on Epstein's case.

events.title: CPAP Machine Delivery Arranged
events.description: Email exchange finalizing the delivery of a CPAP machine for Jeffrey Epstein to the prison medical staff the following Monday.

events.title: SDNY Tour of MCC Following Epstein Death
events.description: The U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York schedules a tour of the Metropolitan Correctional Center to see the suicide watch area, SHU, and Epstein's cordoned-off cell.

events.title: DOJ Statement on Epstein's Death
events.description: Attorney General William P. Barr issues an official statement on the death of Jeffrey Epstein, which is circulated internally within the Bureau of Prisons.

events.title: Epstein Medical Evaluation
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein is evaluated by Dr. Robert Beaudouin. He reports being without his medications for about a week, numbness in his right arm a few days prior, frequent nocturia, history of kidney stones, hypertension, and sleep apnea. He states he has not slept for 3 weeks due to lack of a CPAP machine. New medications and lab tests are ordered.

events.title: Epstein Reports Arm Numbness
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein reports to nurse Joseph Columbo that he woke up with no control over his right arm for a few minutes. He is assessed twice on this date, with follow-up ordered and Dr. Beaudouin notified.

events.title: Administrative Note on Inmate Statement
events.description: Dr. Beaudouin documents that the Mid-Level Practitioner (MLP) notified the Operations Lieutenant (OP LT) of an inmate statement regarding "what happened to him 2 nights ago." A medication for constipation is also ordered.

events.title: Refusal of Optometrist Evaluation
events.description: Dr. Beaudouin documents that Jeffrey Epstein was offered and refused an optometrist evaluation, and a refusal form was signed.

events.title: Epstein Found with Neck Injury in Cell
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was found in his cell (Special Housing Unit Z05-Cell 124 L) with a rope around his neck, sitting on the floor. He was placed on suicide watch. He claimed to not know how the injury occurred.

events.title: Epstein Insinuates Cellmate Involvement
events.description: During a follow-up medical visit, Epstein told provider Y. Joaquin, "I think my room mate had to do with what happened to me," but refused to elaborate further.

events.title: Epstein's BOP Intake Health Screening
events.description: Initial health screening performed by Yoon Kang, documenting Epstein's medical history, including hyperlipidemia, sleep apnea, back pain, and personal history (e.g., travel, sexual partners).

events.title: Chronic Care Physician Evaluations
events.description: Multiple encounters with Dr. Robert Beaudouin to manage Epstein's chronic conditions: hyperlipidemia, obstructive sleep apnea, severe L4-L5 spinal stenosis with back pain, and constipation.

events.title: Initial Medical Intake
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein undergoes initial medical screening upon intake at the Metropolitan Correctional Center, New York (NYM). Provider Yoon Kang notes elevated blood pressure (164/90) and orders follow-up labs and an EKG.

events.title: Comprehensive History & Physical Exam
events.description: Mid-Level Provider Y. Joaquin conducts a full medical history and physical exam on Epstein. Documents social history (occupation: banker, travel to Paris), sexual history (10+ female partners, condom use 'sometimes', past chlamydia), and prescribes medication for constipation.

events.title: Treatment for Back Pain
events.description: Dr. Robert Beaudouin orders a Medrol dose pack for Epstein, who reported shooting pain in the middle of his back, rated 5/10.

events.title: Orders for Insulin and CPAP
events.description: Dr. Robert Beaudouin orders regular insulin via sliding scale twice daily for 7 days and issues a Philips Respironics CPAP machine to Epstein.

events.title: Epstein charged with self-mutilation
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was charged with BOP code 228 (Tattooing or Self-Mutilation), assigned incident report #3282555, leading to a psychological competency evaluation.

events.title: Initial Suicide Risk Assessment
events.description: Chief Psychologist Dr. Elissa Miller conducted a suicide risk assessment on Epstein, where he denied any history of mental health treatment, suicidal ideation, or self-injurious behavior.

events.title: Psychological Competency Evaluation
events.description: Psychologist Dr. Darlene Imeri evaluated Epstein and found him COMPETENT to proceed with the disciplinary process for the July 23 self-injury incident.

events.title: Psych Observation Discontinued
events.description: Following clinical contact and consultation with the Chief Psychologist, psychological observation of Epstein was discontinued.

events.title: Dental Examination
events.description: Dr. Cheryl Ancrum conducted a dental health history and examination on Epstein, noting conditions like gingival recession and crowding.

events.title: Epstein psychological evaluation
events.description: Epstein evaluated by Chief Psychologist Elissa Miller; he denies suicidality, complains about SHU conditions, and claims no memory of how he got neck marks.

events.title: Epstein requests to speak with former cellmate
events.description: During evaluation, Epstein asks to speak with his old cellmate 'Nick' to see if he can help him remember what caused the injuries to his neck.

events.title: Epstein reports sleep deprivation and numbness
events.description: Epstein evaluated by psychologist Darlene Imeri; he reports sleeping only 30 minutes per night in SHU due to noise, and complains of numbness in his arm and neck.

events.title: Epstein reports aversive reaction to toilet noise
events.description: Epstein tells psychologist Imeri that a continuously flushing toilet caused him extreme agitation, leading him to sit in a corner holding his ears, and compares the feeling to being in SHU.

events.title: Epstein's planned return to SHU
events.description: Epstein is told by Chief Psychologist Miller that he will be returned to the Special Housing Unit (SHU) the next day after receiving his CPAP machine for sleep apnea.

events.title: Epstein found with string around neck
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was found in his SHU cell with a string loosely tied around his neck, leading to placement on suicide watch. The circumstances were unclear - whether self-inflicted or caused by his cell mate.

events.title: Post-suicide watch evaluation
events.description: Psychologist Samantha DiMisa evaluated Epstein after 31 hours on suicide watch, found him denying suicidal ideation, and recommended stepping down to psychological observation.

events.title: Suicide risk assessment
events.description: Psychologist Darlene Imeri conducted a suicide risk assessment after the string incident, noting Epstein's vague memory of events and assessing moderate acute suicide risk.

events.title: Epstein placed in SHU
events.description: Epstein was placed in administrative detention in the Special Housing Unit (SHU) at MCC New York.

events.title: Clinical intervention for SHU conditions
events.description: Epstein complained to psychologist Elissa Miller about not receiving basic items like soap and spoons in SHU, and not receiving promised phone calls.

events.title: Epstein returns from court proceeding
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein returned to the Metropolitan Correctional Center after a court proceeding in the evening, prompting staff to place him on precautionary psychological observation.

events.title: Suicide risk assessment conducted
events.description: Chief Psychologist Elissa Miller conducted a formal suicide risk assessment on Jeffrey Epstein at 7:30 AM, finding low acute risk and no history of mental health issues or suicidality.

events.title: Clinical intervention session
events.description: Epstein was seen for a psychological observation contact where he expressed numerous concerns about his jail conditions, including housing, medication, uniforms, and access to property.

events.title: Upcoming bail hearing
events.description: Epstein mentioned during his assessment that he was looking forward to his bail hearing scheduled for Monday, July 15, 2019, though he acknowledged it might take weeks to actually leave jail if granted bail.

events.title: Epstein's Court Proceeding
events.description: Epstein had a court proceeding which, according to the assessment, may have given him bad news regarding his legal situation, prompting precautionary psychological observation upon his return to jail.

events.title: Suicide Risk Assessment
events.description: Dr. Elissa Miller conducted a detailed suicide risk assessment on Jeffrey Epstein, finding his acute suicide risk to be low and chronic risk absent.

events.title: Intake Screening and Risk Assessments
events.description: Psychologist K. Schlessinger conducted initial intake screening and a risk of sexual abusiveness assessment for Epstein upon his arrival at MCC-NY.

events.title: Consultation on Epstein's Risk
events.description: Dr. Miller consulted with Central Office psychologist Dr. Robert Nagle regarding Epstein's risk factors, leading to instructions for staff to notify psychology upon Epstein's return from court.

events.title: Epstein's Blood Sample Collected
events.description: A blood sample was collected from Jeffrey Epstein for laboratory analysis at the Metropolitan Correctional Center.

events.title: Epstein Refuses Chest X-Ray
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein signed a Medical Treatment Refusal form, declining a recommended routine chest X-ray.

events.title: Chronic Care Physician Evaluation
events.description: Dr. Robert Beaudouin conducted a chronic care evaluation of Epstein, noting history of hypertriglyceridemia, sleep apnea, and back pain, and prescribed medication.

events.title: Epstein Found Injured in Cell
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was found in his cell (Special Housing Unit Z05-Cell 124) with a rope around his neck, sitting on the floor. He had marks on his neck and was placed on suicide watch after a medical examination.

events.title: Epstein Refuses Eye Doctor Evaluation
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein signed a Medical Treatment Refusal form, declining a recommended eye doctor evaluation.

events.title: Medical Records Request Emailed
events.description: Legal Assistant Joy Aassiddaa emailed Adam Johnson and Stephanie Scannell, transmitting a request for Jeffrey Epstein's medical records from July 1-24, 2019.

events.title: Epstein's Initial Medical Intake
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein undergoes his initial health screening at the Metropolitan Correctional Center, New York (MCC NY) following his arrest. The screening includes vital signs, medical history, infectious disease risk assessment, and lab orders.

events.title: Comprehensive History and Physical Exam
events.description: A mid-level provider conducts a full history and physical examination on Jeffrey Epstein, documenting detailed past medical, social, and family history, along with a complete physical assessment.

events.title: Chronic Care Physician Evaluation
events.description: Dr. Robert Beaudouin evaluates Jeffrey Epstein for chronic conditions including hyperlipidemia, sleep apnea, and severe lower back pain. New medications are prescribed.

events.title: Epstein Found with String Around Neck
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was found in his SHU cell with a string loosely tied around his neck, leading to his placement on suicide watch. He claimed not to remember the incident and later allegedly told staff his cellmate tried to kill him.

events.title: Initial Medical and Psychological Assessment
events.description: Epstein underwent a medical examination documenting constipation and a psychological suicide risk assessment where he denied any history of mental health issues or suicidal ideation.

events.title: Diagnosis of Multiple Health Issues
events.description: Medical provider Beaudouin diagnosed Epstein with hyperlipidemia, sleep apnea, low back pain, and neuralgia, and prescribed corresponding medications.

events.title: Placement in Administrative Segregation (SHU)
events.description: Epstein was placed in the Special Housing Unit (SHU) under administrative detention status.

events.title: Clinical Intervention Regarding SHU Conditions
events.description: Epstein contacted psychologist Miller to complain about not receiving a spoon, soap, or promised phone calls in SHU. Staff addressed the concerns.

events.title: Epstein returns from court
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein returned from court proceedings in the evening, leading to his placement on precautionary psychological observation status.

events.title: Suicide risk assessment
events.description: Formal suicide risk assessment conducted by Chief Psychologist Elissa Miller. Epstein was found to have low acute suicide risk and absent chronic risk.

events.title: Release from psychological observation
events.description: Epstein was assessed as psychologically stable and released from the psychological observation area to be housed in the 9S area with a cellmate.

events.title: Psychological observation follow-up
events.description: Epstein seen for psychological observation follow-up while in attorney conference. He expressed concerns about incarceration conditions and wearing an orange jumpsuit.

events.title: Risk of Sexual Abusiveness Assessment
events.description: Psychologist K. Schlessinger assesses Jeffrey Epstein's risk of sexual abusiveness within the prison, finding him to be at low risk.

events.title: Placement on Psychological Observation
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein is placed on psychological observation status upon returning from court as a precaution due to identified risk factors for suicidality.

events.title: Psychological Intake Screening
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein undergoes an initial psychological intake evaluation at MCC New York. He denies any history of mental health issues, substance abuse, or being a victim of abuse. He is assessed as Care Level 1 (no significant impairment).

events.title: Medical Laboratory Testing
events.description: Blood tests are collected and analyzed for Jeffrey Epstein, showing high cholesterol, triglycerides, and hemoglobin A1c (indicating prediabetes). Tests for HIV and RPR (syphilis) are negative.

events.title: Refusal of Chest X-Ray
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein refuses a recommended routine chest X-ray, signing a Bureau of Prisons Medical Treatment Refusal form after being counseled on potential consequences.

events.title: Chronic Care Medical Evaluation
events.description: Epstein is evaluated for chronic conditions. He reports being without his medications for a week, numbness in his right arm, nocturia, and an inability to sleep due to lack of his CPAP machine. He is diagnosed with hypertension, prediabetes, hyperlipidemia, sleep apnea, and other issues.

events.title: Cardiac Arrest and Resuscitation Attempt
events.description: At approximately 6:35 AM, a body alarm is activated for a medical emergency. Epstein is found unresponsive on the floor of his cell in the Special Housing Unit, cold, with bruising around the neck and fixed, dilated pupils. CPR is initiated by correctional officers and continued by medical staff. Paramedics arrive, intubate him, and administer epinephrine and sodium bicarbonate. He is transported to a local ER with CPR in progress.

events.title: Medical Records Request
events.description: Legal Assistant Joy Aassiddaa emails Adam Johnson and Stephanie Scannell to request Jeffrey Epstein's medical records for the period from July 6, 2019, to August 28, 2019.

events.title: Epstein Found with Rope Around Neck
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was found in his cell (Special Housing Unit Z05-Cell 124) with a rope around his neck, sitting on the floor. He claimed to not know how it happened, stating he 'went to drink a little water and wake up snorting'.

events.title: Placement on Suicide Watch
events.description: Following the incident where he was found with a rope around his neck, Epstein was placed on suicide watch by Bureau of Prisons staff.

events.title: Reports of Right Arm Numbness
events.description: Epstein reported to nursing staff that he woke up with no control over his right arm for a few minutes, describing numbness and 'pins and needles' that had occurred days prior.

events.title: Comprehensive Medical Evaluation
events.description: Dr. Beaudouin conducted a chronic care clinic encounter with Epstein, noting multiple complaints (numbness, lack of sleep without CPAP, constipation) and ordering new medications and diagnostic tests (lab work, cervical spine X-ray).

events.title: Follow-up Chronic Care Evaluation
events.description: Dr. Beaudouin conducts another evaluation, confirming diagnoses and ordering long-term medication (Vascepa) for Epstein's hyperlipidemia. Future clinic appointments are scheduled.

events.title: Medical Note Cosign
events.description: Dr. Beaudouin cosigns a medical note from provider Y. Joaquin, part of the ongoing documentation of Epstein's healthcare.

events.title: Initial Medical Intake and PPD Test
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein's initial medical intake at MCC New York, including administration of a PPD test for tuberculosis by PA-C Kang.

events.title: Comprehensive Health Screening
events.description: A detailed intake health screening performed by MLP Joaquin, recording Epstein's full medical history, physical exam, and baseline vitals.

events.title: CPAP Machine Issued and Insulin Prescribed
events.description: Dr. Beaudouin prescribed a regular insulin sliding scale and issued a Philips Respironics CPAP machine for Epstein's sleep apnea.

events.title: Medical Transfer Form Prepared
events.description: Nurse Columbo completed a 'Transfer To' medical form summarizing Epstein's health problems, medications, and restrictions, possibly in preparation for a facility transfer.

events.title: Neck Injury Incident
events.description: An incident where Epstein had marks on his neck, documented as 'R/O self inflicted injuries' in his health problems. Referenced in a later suicide risk assessment.

events.title: CPAP Machine Issued
events.description: Epstein was issued a CPAP machine (Philips Respironics System One) for sleep apnea, with equipment start date noted.

events.title: Suicide Risk Assessment Triggered by Marshals
events.description: US Marshals reported Epstein had 'suicidal tendencies' upon his return from court, prompting a suicide risk assessment by psychologist Darlene Imeri.

events.title: Psychology Follow-up Session
events.description: Chief Psychologist Elissa Miller conducted a follow-up session with Epstein in the SHU. Epstein reported feeling okay, denied mental health symptoms, and spent days with his attorneys.

events.title: Epstein found with string around neck in SHU
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was found by staff in his cell in the Special Housing Unit (SHU) with a string loosely tied around his neck. He stated he did not remember anything about it, leading to an incident report and psychological assessments.

events.title: Competency evaluation for disciplinary process
events.description: Psychologist Darlene Imeri evaluated Epstein's competency to proceed with the disciplinary process for incident report #3282555, related to the July 23 event (charged with code 228: Tattooing or Self-Mutilation). He was found competent.

events.title: Follow-up after removal from Psychological Observation
events.description: Epstein was seen by psychologist Jolie Avena for a follow-up after being removed from Psychological Observation. He reported doing as well as expected, was going to court for a status hearing, and denied suicidal ideation.

events.title: Comprehensive suicide risk assessment
events.description: Psychologist Darlene Imeri conducted a detailed suicide risk assessment, noting both risk and protective factors. Epstein was assessed as having low acute suicide risk and absent chronic suicide risk.

events.title: Epstein Placed on Suicide Watch
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was placed on suicide watch following an incident in the Special Housing Unit (SHU) that resulted in marks and a scab on his neck. The exact nature of the incident is unclear.

events.title: Epstein Removed from Suicide Watch
events.description: Psychologist Samantha DiMisa completed a post-suicide watch report, assessing Epstein's suicide risk as low and stepping him down to psychological observation.

events.title: Daily Psychological Observation
events.description: Epstein remained on psychological observation from July 24-28, 2019, with daily evaluations by psychology staff. He interacted with inmate companions, attended legal visits, and continued to claim no memory of the neck injury incident.

events.title: Placement in SHU
events.description: Epstein is placed in the Special Housing Unit (SHU) under administrative detention. He expresses numerous complaints about conditions.

events.title: String Incident and Suicide Watch
events.description: At about 2 AM, Epstein is found in his SHU cell with a string loosely tied around his neck. He is placed on suicide watch. He later tells staff his cellmate tried to kill him, but denies remembering the incident to the psychologist.

events.title: Formal Suicide Risk Assessment
events.description: Dr. Darlene Imeri conducts a formal suicide risk assessment on Epstein following the string incident. Epstein denies suicidal ideation but has a circular mark on his neck. Overall acute suicide risk is assessed as 'Moderate'.

events.title: Psychological assessment conducted
events.description: Chief Psychologist Elissa Miller conducted suicide risk assessments and diagnostic evaluations of Jeffrey Epstein, finding low acute suicide risk and no mental health diagnosis.

events.title: Assessment amendment
events.description: Elissa Miller amended the psychological assessment notes, maintaining the same conclusions about Epstein's low suicide risk and lack of mental health issues.

events.title: Epstein Intake and Risk Assessments
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein undergoes BOP psychological intake screening and a risk of sexual abusiveness assessment upon arrival at MCC New York. He is assessed as low risk for sexual abusiveness and having no need for regular mental health intervention.

events.title: Consultation on Epstein Suicide Risk
events.description: Dr. Elissa Miller consults with Dr. Robert Nagle regarding Epstein's risk factors for suicidality due to his high-profile case and upcoming court proceedings. Staff are instructed to notify psychology if he returns from court distressed.

events.title: Epstein Suicide Risk Assessment
events.description: Dr. Elissa Miller conducts a formal suicide risk assessment on Jeffrey Epstein. He is found to have a low acute suicide risk and an absent chronic suicide risk. He is future-oriented, denies suicidal ideation, and references an upcoming bail hearing.

events.title: Epstein Laboratory Tests Collected
events.description: Blood is collected from Jeffrey Epstein for comprehensive chemistry, hematology, and serology tests, including HIV and RPR screening.

events.title: Epstein Refuses Rectal/Genital Exam
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein refuses a recommended rectal and genital examination, counseled by Y. Joaquin and Robert Beaudouin.

events.title: Epstein Dental Examination
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein undergoes a dental examination at MCC New York conducted by C. Ancrum, DDS.

events.title: Washington Post Article on Democratic Primary
events.description: The Washington Post publishes an analysis of the 2020 Democratic primary, focusing on generational change and candidate strategies.

events.title: New Hampshire Democratic Party Convention
events.description: Nineteen Democratic presidential candidates speak at the New Hampshire Democratic Party's annual convention, a key campaign event.

events.title: Collapse of Afghanistan Peace Talks
events.description: President Trump canceled a secret Camp David meeting with Afghan and Taliban leaders, exposing internal administration divisions and halting U.S.-Taliban negotiations.

events.title: Brexit Negotiations and Early Election Push
events.description: British Parliament expected to reject PM Boris Johnson's call for early elections as he seeks to finalize Brexit by October 31.

events.title: Hurricane Dorian Aftermath
events.description: U.S. humanitarian response continues in the Bahamas; NOAA investigates its response to Trump's tweets about the hurricane.

events.title: Congress Returns from Recess
events.description: Congress returns with agenda including government funding, gun control, trade, and drug pricing.

events.title: Hong Kong Protests and U.S. Consulate March
events.description: Thousands of pro-democracy protesters marched to the U.S. Consulate in Hong Kong seeking support, leading to later violence.

events.title: Publication and Review of 'She Said'
events.description: The book 'She Said' by Jodi Kantor and Megan Twohey is published, detailing their investigation into Harvey Weinstein's sexual misconduct and the efforts to conceal it.

events.title: MIT President Responds to Epstein Donation Allegations
events.description: MIT President L. Rafael Reif responds to allegations in the New Yorker that Joi Ito sought to conceal Epstein donations, calls it 'deeply disturbing', and announces Ito's resignation and an external review.

events.title: MIT President Apologizes to Epstein's Victims
events.description: MIT President L. Rafael Reif apologizes to Jeffrey Epstein's victims in a campus message, revealing the school accepted about $800,000 from Epstein over 20 years.

events.title: Epstein's $6.5 Million Gift to Harvard
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein made his largest gift to Harvard University: $6.5 million for the Program for Evolutionary Dynamics.

events.title: MIT Media Lab Director Resigns Over Epstein Ties
events.description: MIT President L. Rafael Reif announces the resignation of Joi Ito as director of the Media Lab following allegations he concealed the source of donations from Jeffrey Epstein.

events.title: Epstein's $6.5 Million Donation to Harvard
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein made a $6.5 million gift to Harvard University for the Program for Evolutionary Dynamics.

events.title: Internal Email Regarding Epstein's Incarceration
events.description: An internal email with subject 'Re: UM Epstein #76318-054' is forwarded, likely concerning administrative details of Epstein's prison designation.

events.title: Inquiry on Epstein's Mental Capacity
events.description: Glenda Anderson-Layne emails Chief Psychologist Elissa Miller to inquire whether inmate Jeffrey Epstein is mentally capable of proceeding with the disciplinary process.

events.title: Epstein's Last Full Day
events.description: Epstein's cellmate departs for court at 8:00 am. Epstein is in attorney conferences throughout the day until 6:45 pm, then returns to SHU. At 7:00 pm, he is provided a social call and reported to be in good spirits.

events.title: Notification and Investigation Initiated
events.description: Multiple agencies are notified: USMS, SIS, FBI, AUSA, Judge Berman, OIG. The FBI arrives at 12:19 pm. OIG is notified and sends agents. The body is released to the Medical Examiner for autopsy.

events.title: Staff Recall and FBI Investigation
events.description: A staff recall is conducted at 1:00 pm. The FBI arrives at 3:14 pm, departs at 7:56 pm, returns at 9:45 pm, and departs again at 10:30 pm.

events.title: Post-Incident Review Team Arrives
events.description: Mr. Hollingsworth, Dr. Robert Negle, Dr. Kristin Willert, and Northeast Regional Director R. Ormond arrive at the institution for review.

events.title: Epstein Placed on Psychological Observation/Suicide Watch
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was placed under psychological observation/suicide watch at the Metropolitan Correctional Center, New York. A detailed log tracks his meals, liquids, showers, and behavior.

events.title: Email Distribution of Psych Observation Report
events.description: An email from Lomat N'Diaye is sent distributing the psychological observation report for Jeffrey Epstein from July 8-10, 2019, with attachments including the log and a PDF.
