keyFacts: Jeffrey Epstein was under psychological observation/suicide watch at MCC New York from July 24 to July 30, 2019, as documented in an attached log.
An email chain from early August 2019 shows administrative coordination for a telephonic SDNY court hearing for another inmate, Wilbert Kitson Turner.
The email explicitly notes that Jeffrey Epstein was expected to have an attorney visit on the same day (August 8, 2019), creating a scheduling conflict for conference room space at the MCC.
The document provides a direct administrative link between Epstein's incarceration status and the routine operations of the federal prison in New York.
Inmate Nicholas 'Nick' Turner was placed in the SHU at MCC-NY in July 2019 for an alleged cell phone possession violation.
Turner's defense attorney, Bruce Barket, complained of poor conditions in the SHU cell, including a leaking toilet, wet floor, and lack of personal property like books and a radio.
Barket raised a significant concern that privileged attorney-client work product documents were seized from Turner when he was moved to SHU and had not been returned.
A status conference for Turner's civil case, Turner v. Ulloa, was rescheduled from August 9, 2019, to August 8, 2019, with Turner to participate by phone from MCC.
The email chain shows coordination between MCC legal staff (Adam Johnson, Stephanie Scannell) and federal prosecutors (Jason Swergold, Michael Gerber) regarding Turner's situation.

An inmate named 'Nick' was placed in the SHU at the MCC in early July 2019 for alleged cell phone possession, prompting his attorney Bruce Barket to complain about poor conditions including a leaking toilet and confiscated privileged legal work.
Attorney Jonathan Savella contacted MCC staff on August 5, 2019, to request help establishing a telephone account for Jeffrey Epstein, indicating Epstein was still alive and in custody at that time.

A news article from August 12, 2019, cites Attorney General William Barr acknowledging 'serious irregularities' at the federal lockup where Jeffrey Epstein died, indicating an ongoing investigation into the circumstances of his death.
A news article from August 19, 2019, reports Jeffrey Epstein signed a will worth $577 million just two days before his suicide.
The email chain shows coordination between federal prosecutors (SDNY) and prison legal staff regarding inmate welfare issues at the MCC, highlighting administrative procedures.
Jeffrey Epstein signed a will worth $577 million just two days before his suicide on August 10, 2019.
One witness to Epstein's will was lawyer Mariel Colon Miro, who had previously worked for Mexican drug lord El Chapo.
Video surveillance footage from the time of Epstein's first suicide attempt in July 2019 was reported missing.
Internal BOP emails show planning for a U.S. Attorney's Office visit to inspect the MCC, including Epstein's cell, shortly after his death.
The document includes a mix of breaking news, internal agency correspondence, and unrelated news clippings from late 2019.
Jeffrey Epstein was under psychological observation/suicide watch from at least July 24 to July 30, 2019.
Detailed logs of his condition, meals, and activities during this period were compiled into a PDF report.
Associate Warden Charisma Edge formally transmitted this report via email on August 12, 2019, to other Bureau of Prisons officials.
The document metadata indicates the email was later tagged as 'Responsive' and 'Flagged' during a review process in May 2020.
The observation logs utilized an 'I/M companion' (Inmate Companion), a procedure where another inmate is assigned to monitor a prisoner on suicide watch.
Jeffrey Epstein (Registration No. 73618-054) was on a formal psychological observation/suicide watch from July 24 to July 30, 2019.
The document includes a detailed meal and shower chart for Epstein during this observation period, indicating close monitoring.
Handwritten notes within the log are largely illegible but appear to be real-time behavioral observations of the inmate.
An email dated August 12, 2019, was sent to transmit this observation log, indicating official record-keeping of his prison status.
The document is part of the Bureau of Prisons (BOP) records, tagged as 'Responsive' and 'Flagged' in May 2020.
The document contains a suicide watch/psych observation log form, though the inmate's name is not clearly legible in the provided text.
A court order dated January 8, 2020, mandates an update on inmate Anthony Scott's mental health treatment by March 10, 2020.
The email chain shows coordination between Bureau of Prisons (BOP) legal staff and the U.S. Attorney's Office (Samson Enzer) in response to a judicial order.
The document is part of case 1:15-cr-00537 (USA v. Conyers et al), which is separate from the Epstein case but included in this document set.

Prosecutors from the SDNY U.S. Attorney's Office planned a detailed visit to the MCC in August 2019 to inspect areas related to Jeffrey Epstein's incarceration, including his cell which was still cordoned off.
The visit request specified that only MCC legal staff should escort the prosecutors and that they would not speak to guards due to ongoing investigations.
A separate email chain shows BOP legal staff coordinating with federal prosecutors regarding a court order in an unrelated case (USA v. Conyers et al.).
The document provides evidence of post-Epstein death investigative activity by the SDNY U.S. Attorney's Office at the MCC.
The email regarding the MCC visit is addressed from a redacted sender (likely an AUSA) to BOP staff, indicating formal protocol for such inquiries.
SDNY prosecutors requested a tour of the MCC, specifically asking to see Epstein's cell, the psych observation area, and the SHU, indicating an investigation into the circumstances of his death.
An Associated Press reporter inquired about imminent criminal charges against two MCC employees for 'lapses' the night Epstein died, suggesting potential negligence charges.
A Miami Herald investigation revealed systemic sexual abuse of female inmates by male officers at the Coleman Federal Correctional Complex, leading to a lawsuit.
Internal BOP emails show officials scrambling to compile data on sexual abuse allegations (2014-2018) in response to the DOJ's questions about the Miami Herald report.
The Miami Herald article explicitly links the dysfunction revealed by the Coleman abuse scandal to the broader failure of the BOP system, exemplified by Jeffrey Epstein's death while in custody.
BOP Office of Internal Affairs data shows hundreds of staff/inmate sexual abuse cases annually from FY2014-2019, with charges sustained in fewer than 5% of cases.

A Miami Herald investigation and subsequent lawsuit allege systemic, brazen sexual abuse by male officers at the women's work camp at Coleman Federal Correctional Complex, with officers using threats and intimidation.
Internal BOP emails show officials were unaware of the specific allegations at Coleman until the article was published, prompting internal coordination on how to respond to DOJ inquiries.
The document references Jeffrey Epstein's death in BOP custody on August 10, 2019, as an example of the prison system's dysfunction, which led to the removal of Acting Director Hugh Hurwitz.
The BOP declined a Miami Herald request for personnel files of named officers, citing privacy concerns and lack of overriding public interest.
A Miami Herald investigation and subsequent lawsuit allege systemic, brazen sexual abuse by male officers against female inmates at the Coleman Federal Correctional Complex women's camp.
Internal BOP emails show officials scrambling to formulate a response to media inquiries, including compiling statistics on sexual abuse allegations from FY 2014-2019.
BOP data shows hundreds of staff/inmate sexual abuse cases reported each year (e.g., 516 in FY 2018, 439 in FY 2019), but charges are sustained in fewer than 5% of cases.

Following Jeffrey Epstein's death, the US Attorney's office for the SDNY requested and was granted a tour of the MCC's SHU, suicide watch areas, and Epstein's cell, with instructions not to speak to guards due to ongoing investigations.
The document contains an email with an attachment titled 'Epstein, Jeffrey Reg. No. 76318-054X.docx', indicating internal BOP record-keeping and communication about Epstein shortly after his death.
Jeffrey Epstein was found unresponsive in his cell at the MCC New York SHU at 6:33 am on August 10, 2019, and was pronounced dead at a hospital at 7:36 am.
Epstein's cellmate, Reyes Efrain, had been removed from the cell the previous morning to go to court.
The FBI and OIG were notified and began investigations on the day of the death. OIG agents seized two computers from the SHU the following day.
An internal BOP email from October 2019 reveals that Epstein's suicide caused wardens to default to keeping inmates on suicide watch longer than psychologists advised, prompting a policy memo.
The document includes a heavily handwritten form titled 'Psych Observation 7/8/19 6 pm until 7/10/19 at 9 am,' suggesting psychological monitoring in the days before his death.
A Miami Herald investigation alleged systemic sexual abuse of female inmates by male officers at Coleman Federal Correctional Complex, with a lawsuit filed by 14 women.
The Bureau of Prisons (BOP) email chain shows officials discussing how to respond to inquiries about sexual abuse statistics and investigations for FY 2014-2019.
An attached BOP form documents that Jeffrey Epstein was placed on a psychological observation from July 8 to July 10, 2019, prior to his death in August 2019.
The email correspondence indicates BOP's Office of Internal Affairs investigates all allegations of staff misconduct, including sexual abuse.
The document references Jeffrey Epstein's death by hanging on August 10, 2019, at the Metropolitan Correctional Center, which followed a reported previous suicide attempt.
Jeffrey Epstein was on a formal psychological observation/suicide watch from July 8 to July 10, 2019, while in federal custody.
A detailed observation log was maintained, including a chart tracking his meals, liquids, and showers.

The document shows internal Bureau of Prisons email correspondence among staff (Lanett N'Diaye, Lee Plourde, Adam Johnson, Elissa Miller, Jermaine Darden, Shirley V. Skipper-Scott) regarding Epstein's status.
Epstein's Bureau of Prisons registration number is listed as 76318-054 (with variations 73618-054 and 76318-054X).
The observation protocol specified strict items allowed (e.g., safety toothbrush, safety pen) and required use of a suicide smock and blanket if no other items were approved.
Epstein's cellmate, Reyes Efrain, had departed for court on August 9 and did not return to the institution that night, leaving Epstein alone in the cell.
Computer hard drives were removed from the SHU computers and replaced on the night of August 10, 2019, shortly after Epstein's death.

The US Attorney's office for the Southern District of New York, led by Geoffrey Berman, requested a tour of the SHU and Epstein's cell for August 15, 2019, specifying they did not want to speak to guards due to ongoing investigations.
The document provides a detailed, minute-by-minute timeline of the institutional response, including notifications to the FBI, OIG, Judge Berman, and Epstein's next of kin (his brother).

The US Attorney's Office for the SDNY requested a tour of the MCC's suicide watch area, Special Housing Unit (SHU), and Jeffrey Epstein's still-cordoned-off cell on August 15, 2019, following his death.
The request specified that only MCC legal staff should escort them and they would not speak to guards due to ongoing investigations.
In late August 2019, a media inquiry revealed reports of raw sewage flooding jail cells and common areas at the MCC, with female detainees allegedly asked to clean the mess.
The media inquiry directly linked staffing shortages and visitation denials at the MCC to the wake of Epstein's suicide, asking what steps the BOP had taken.
The BOP's official response confirmed a sewage backup that was repaired by noon on August 26, 2019, and acknowledged a temporary visitation delay on Saturday due to staffing.
In November 2019, the Associated Press was investigating that two MCC employees were about to be charged regarding security lapses the night Jeffrey Epstein died.
BOP staff internally decided not to respond to the AP's media inquiry about legal representation for the MCC staff.

In July 2019, Jeffrey Epstein's attorney, Jonathan Savella, was in direct contact with BOP staff to arrange the delivery of a CPAP machine for Epstein, which was approved and required delivery to medical staff.
The email correspondence shows logistical planning for Epstein's medical care (CPAP machine) just weeks before his death.
The document contains internal BOP email tags from 2020 marking these communications as 'Responsive' and 'Flagged' in relation to a BOP case (BOP01703).
Jeffrey Epstein's attorney, Jonathan Savella, was coordinating the delivery of a CPAP machine to him in prison just weeks before his death.
A new paralegal, Samanta Honigman, was being added to Epstein's legal team in July 2019.
Epstein's inmate number was 76318-054.
A Google Alert from August 26, 2019, references Epstein's suicide on August 10, 2019, and the subsequent shake-up at the Bureau of Prisons.
The correspondence shows routine administrative interactions between Epstein's legal team and the BOP regarding his care and legal representation.
SDNY prosecutors, including U.S. Attorney Geoffrey Berman, requested a tour of the MCC's suicide watch area, Special Housing Unit (SHU), and Jeffrey Epstein's cell, which was still cordoned off.
The prosecutors specified they would only be escorted by MCC legal staff and would not speak to any guards due to ongoing investigations.
The visit was scheduled for August 15, 2019, just days after Epstein's death on August 10, 2019.
Attorney General William Barr's official statement on Epstein's death was circulated internally within the Bureau of Prisons via email.
The correspondence shows immediate investigative steps taken by the U.S. Attorney's Office following Epstein's death in federal custody.

Jeffrey Epstein's medical records from late July 2019 document multiple health complaints including right arm numbness, lack of medication, sleep apnea without a CPAP machine, hypertension, and prediabetes.
An administrative note dated July 26, 2019, references an inmate statement about "what happened to him 2 nights ago," which was escalated to the Operations Lieutenant.
An Associated Press inquiry from November 2019 indicates that, shortly after Epstein's death, there was an expectation that two MCC employees would be charged regarding lapses the night he died.
Epstein refused an optometrist evaluation on July 24, 2019, signing a refusal form.
The medical records show Epstein was prescribed medications for constipation, prediabetes, and neuralgia during this period.
On July 23, 2019, Jeffrey Epstein was found in his cell with a rope around his neck; custody staff reported this as a possible self-inflicted injury, and he was placed on suicide watch.

The next day (July 24), during a medical follow-up, Epstein insinuated to a provider that his cellmate "had to do with what happened to me," but he refused to provide details or formally accuse anyone.
Medical notes describe a "circular line of erythema at the base of the neck" consistent with a rope injury, with Epstein showing no apparent distress and smiling during the clinical encounter.

Epstein had several chronic health conditions documented, including severe hyperlipidemia, obstructive sleep apnea (for which he used a CPAP machine confiscated by the FBI), and severe L4-L5 spinal stenosis causing shooting back pain.

The intake health screening from July 6, 2019, recorded Epstein's personal history, including stating he had "10+" female sexual partners in the last 5 years, sometimes used condoms, and had traveled to Paris for three weeks prior to his arrest.
Epstein's medical intake on July 6, 2019, showed elevated blood pressure (164/90), but he denied a history of hypertension.

During a physical exam on July 9, 2019, Epstein reported having "10+" female sexual partners in the last five years and "sometimes" using condoms. He also reported a history of chlamydia in 2015, which was treated.
Epstein denied any history of mental health treatment, head injury, suicide attempts, or current suicidal ideation during assessments on July 6 and July 9.
Medical records show Epstein was issued a CPAP machine and had an insulin order initiated on July 30, 2019, indicating management of sleep apnea and blood sugar issues.
Epstein refused parts of the physical exam on July 9, specifically the rectal and male genitalia examinations.
Jeffrey Epstein was diagnosed with multiple health conditions including hyperlipidemia, sleep apnea, hypertension, prediabetes, and low back pain while in BOP custody.

Epstein was prescribed medications including steroids (methylPREDNISolone), omega-3 fatty acids (Vascepa), stool softeners, and was slated to begin insulin, indicating management of various conditions.

A psychological report details an incident on July 23, 2019, where Epstein was charged with 'Tattooing or Self-Mutilation' (code 228) after being found with marks on his neck; he claimed not to remember how they got there.
Epstein had a documented fish allergy, for which a modified diet was requested, and was prescribed a CPAP machine for sleep apnea.

Psychological evaluations concluded Epstein was competent to participate in disciplinary proceedings and was not on suicide watch, though he expressed distress about sleeping in the noisy Special Housing Unit (SHU).
Jeffrey Epstein repeatedly claimed to have no memory of how he sustained marks and a scab on his neck while in the Special Housing Unit (SHU).
Epstein expressed anxiety about returning to the SHU, citing it as a place where he got injured, it was noisy, smelly, and felt like punishment.
Clinical staff noted Epstein was future-oriented, denied suicidal ideation, and was actively engaged with his attorneys during legal visits.
Epstein reported severe sleep deprivation in SHU (only 30 minutes per night) and was awaiting a CPAP machine for his sleep apnea.
Epstein requested to speak with his former SHU cellmate 'Nick' to see if he could help him remember the incident that caused his neck injuries.
On July 23, 2019, Jeffrey Epstein was found in his SHU cell with a string loosely tied around his neck, resulting in a circular scar and placement on suicide watch.
Epstein consistently denied suicidal ideation and intent during psychological evaluations, stating he had 'lots to do for his legal case' and that it would be 'crazy' to take his life.
Epstein reported memory loss about the string incident, claiming he only remembered drinking water, then hearing himself snore and waking on a stretcher.
Epstein expressed fear for his safety if returned to his previous cell, stating his cell mate had called him a 'pedophile' and was reading newspaper articles about him.

Psychological assessments identified risk factors including high-profile crime, sex offender status, lack of family connections, and fear for safety, but protective factors included future orientation and denial of suicidal intent.

Jeffrey Epstein was assessed as having low acute suicide risk and no chronic suicide risk on July 9, 2019, despite having risk factors like high-profile case, sex trafficking charges, and pre-trial status.
Epstein denied any history of mental health treatment, psychotropic medication use, suicidal ideation, or substance abuse during the evaluation.
Epstein was placed on precautionary psychological observation after returning from court on July 8, 2019, due to concerns about potential bad news from his legal proceeding.

During a clinical contact on July 10, 2019, Epstein made multiple requests about jail conditions including not wanting to be in SHU, wanting single-cell housing, specific medication for constipation, and not wanting to wear an orange uniform to legal visits.
Epstein expressed optimism about his upcoming bail hearing on July 15, 2019, and described himself as a banker with a 'big business' in the community.

On July 9-10, 2019, a BOP suicide risk assessment found Jeffrey Epstein's acute suicide risk to be 'Low' and chronic risk 'Absent', despite identifying static risk factors like his sex offender status, high-profile case, and lack of family connections.
Epstein explicitly and adamantly denied any recent or current suicidal ideation, intention, or plan during the assessment, was future-oriented, and expressed a commitment to life and safety.
Epstein reported his only family was a brother with whom he did not have a close relationship, but stated he had a support system of friends and associates in the community.
A separate BOP assessment on July 8, 2019, judged Epstein to be at 'Low Risk of Abusiveness' for sexual behavior within the facility, though he declined sex offender treatment programming.
Epstein reported a previous incarceration of three months for prostitution (soliciting prostitution) in Palm Beach County and was currently charged with federal sex trafficking.

On July 23, 2019, Jeffrey Epstein was found in his cell (Special Housing Unit Z05-Cell 124) with a rope around his neck, sitting on the floor, resulting in a circular line of erythema (redness) on his neck.

The medical report from the July 23 incident states Epstein told the provider, 'I do not know. Just went to drink a little water and wake up snorting,' and that he did not want to talk about the events leading to the marks.
Following the July 23 incident, Epstein was placed on suicide watch and referred for follow-up with psychology services.
Epstein refused multiple recommended medical treatments while in custody, including a chest X-ray on July 10, 2019, and an eye doctor evaluation on July 24, 2019.

Epstein's lab results from July 9-10, 2019, showed elevated triglycerides (413 mg/dL), elevated cholesterol (216 mg/dL), low HDL (31 mg/dL), and a Hemoglobin A1c of 6.3%, indicating increased risk for diabetes.

Jeffrey Epstein's medical records reveal multiple health issues at the time of his incarceration, including severe L4-L5 spinal stenosis causing numbness and shooting pain, hyperlipidemia (triglycerides at 800), sleep apnea requiring CPAP, and constipation.
Epstein reported a history of chlamydia in 2015 (treated) and stated he had '10+' female sexual partners in the last 5 years, with 'sometimes' condom use.
Epstein denied any history of physical, emotional, or sexual abuse when asked during the intake screening.
The records show Epstein was actively receiving medical care and medication management (e.g., Methylprednisolone for pain, docusate for constipation) in the weeks leading up to his death.
Epstein's stated occupation is listed as 'Banker' and his education as 'High school diploma' in the social history.
On July 23, 2019, Jeffrey Epstein was found in his SHU cell with a string loosely tied around his neck, leading to a suicide watch placement and a psychological assessment.
Epstein allegedly told staff his cellmate tried to kill him, though he later denied remembering the incident to the psychologist.
Medical records from July 2019 show Epstein was diagnosed with several health issues including constipation, hyperlipidemia, sleep apnea, and low back pain.
A suicide risk assessment noted static risk factors including 'High Profile Crime', 'Lack of family connections', and 'Sex offender status'.
Epstein had been placed in administrative detention in the SHU on July 10, 2019, and was awaiting a court hearing.

Jeffrey Epstein was assessed as having low acute suicide risk and absent chronic suicide risk despite having risk factors including high-profile case, sex offense charges, and lack of family connections.
Epstein consistently denied any history of mental health treatment, suicidal ideation, or substance abuse, stating it was 'well-known' he didn't drink alcohol.
Epstein expressed numerous complaints about prison conditions including wanting a different uniform for legal visits, constipation medication (Colace), and dissatisfaction with SHU housing.
Epstein revealed he had only one family member, a brother with whom he did not have a close relationship, but claimed to have a support system of friends and associates in the community.
The psychological records show Epstein was future-oriented, expressed commitment to life, and was anticipating his bail hearing while maintaining he did nothing wrong in prison.

On July 9, 2019, a BOP psychologist assessed Jeffrey Epstein as having a 'Low' acute suicide risk and 'Absent' chronic suicide risk, despite having risk factors like a high-profile case and sex offense charges.
Epstein adamantly denied any past or present suicidal ideation, intention, or plan during the assessment, was future-oriented, and expressed a commitment to life and safety.
Epstein reported his only family was a brother with whom he had no relationship, but stated he had a support system of friends and associates in the community.
A separate assessment on July 8, 2019, found Epstein to be at 'Low Risk of Abusiveness' for sexual behavior within the prison, based on his history of sexual abuse perpetration in the community.
Epstein expressed confidence in his attorney, described him as 'competent,' and reported he was going to have a bail hearing and believed he would be released from jail.
Jeffrey Epstein was found unresponsive in his cell at MCC New York on the morning of August 10, 2019, with 'circumferential bruising around the neck' and posterior mottling.
